questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : ENGLISH I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : ENGLISH I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"

questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:  Nature is an infinite source of beauty. Sunrise and sunset, mountains and rivers, lakes and glaciers, forests and fields provide joy and bliss to the human mind and heart for hours together. Everything in nature is splendid and divine. Every day and every season of the year has a peculiar beauty to unfold. Only, one should have the eyes to behold it and a heart to feel it, like the English poet William Wordsworth who, after seeing daffodils, said: "And then my heart with pleasure fills and dances with the daffodils.” Nature is a great teacher. The early man was thrilled with the beauty and the wonders of nature. The Aryans worshiped nature. One can learn a great many lessons in the vast school of nature.  Unfortunately, the strife, the stress and the tension of modern life have made people immune to the beauties of nature. Their life is so full of care that they have no time to stand and stare. They cannot enjoy the beauty of flowing rivers, swinging trees, flying birds and majestic mountains and hills. There is however, a cry to go back to the village from the concrete and artificial jungles that are our cities. Hence, the town planners of today pay special attention to provide a sufficient number of natural scenic spots in the towns that they plan. To develop a balanced personality, one needs to have a healthy attitude which can make one appreciate and enjoy the beauty of nature. There is no other balm to soothe our tired souls and listless minds than the infinite beauty of nature all around us. We should enjoy it fully to lead a balanced and harmonious life, full of peace and tranquility.

questions.question_text_1: What, according to the passage, is needed to develop a balanced personality?
question_texts: What, according to the passage, is needed to develop a balanced personality?

options.option_text: Going back to villages after shunning our cities
A healthy attitude which can help us appreciate nature
Reading poetry by the likes of William Wordsworth
Interpersonal skills, as taught by nature

questions.question_text_1: What, according to the passage, leads to a balanced and harmonious life full of peace and tranquility?
question_texts: What, according to the passage, leads to a balanced and harmonious life full of peace and tranquility?

options.option_text: Fully enjoying the infinite beauty of nature all around us
Lead a disciplined and dedicated life.
Find a scenic spot in the town one inhabits.
Get totally immersed in our daily routine.

question_texts: On the basis of your reading of the passage, fill in the blank.  Their life is so full of care that _____.

options.option_text: They feel splendid and divine no more.
Their sun does not set anymore.
They have no time to stand and stare.
They forget their hearts for hours together.

To develop a balanced personality, one needs to have a healthy attitude which can make one appreciate and enjoy the beauty of nature. There is no other balm to soothe our tired souls and listless minds than the infinite beauty of nature all around us. We should enjoy it fully to lead a balanced and harmonious life, full of peace and tranquility.
question_texts: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:  Nature is an infinite source of beauty. Sunrise and sunset, mountains and rivers, lakes and glaciers, forests and fields provide joy and bliss to the human mind and heart for hours together. Everything in nature is splendid and divine. Every day and every season of the year has a peculiar beauty to unfold. Only, one should have the eyes to behold it and a heart to feel it, like the English poet William Wordsworth who, after seeing daffodils, said: "And then my heart with pleasure fills and dances with the daffodils.” Nature is a great teacher. The early man was thrilled with the beauty and the wonders of nature. The Aryans worshiped nature. One can learn a great many lessons in the vast school of nature.  Unfortunately, the strife, the stress and the tension of modern life have made people immune to the beauties of nature. Their life is so full of care that they have no time to stand and stare. They cannot enjoy the beauty of flowing rivers, swinging trees, flying birds and majestic mountains and hills. There is however, a cry to go back to the village from the concrete and artificial jungles that are our cities. Hence, the town planners of today pay special attention to provide a sufficient number of natural scenic spots in the towns that they plan. To develop a balanced personality, one needs to have a healthy attitude which can make one appreciate and enjoy the beauty of nature. There is no other balm to soothe our tired souls and listless minds than the infinite beauty of nature all around us. We should enjoy it fully to lead a balanced and harmonious life, full of peace and tranquility.

questions.question_text_1: On the basis of your reading of the passage, fill in the blank with a fitting adjective.  _____ mountains.
question_texts: On the basis of your reading of the passage, fill in the blank with a fitting adjective.  _____ mountains.

questions.question_text_1: Read the following telephone conversation and answer the given subquestions:   Jenny: Hello! Good morning! Am I speaking to someone at the Purchase Department?  Lena: Yes. (i) _________.  Jenny: May I speak with Jonathan?  Lena: He is not around.  Jenny: (ii) _________________.  Lena: Sure. But (iii) ______________.  Jenny: Oh! Let me (iv) ______to you later.  Lena: OK! Thank you!

props.summary:
### **Exam Summary: Qualifier Level – English I (Computer-Based Exam)**

This exam tests **English language proficiency** across multiple dimensions, including:
1. **Reading Comprehension** (Passage-based questions)
2. **Vocabulary & Word Usage** (Synonyms, Antonyms, Word Sounds, Collocations)
3. **Grammar & Syntax** (Parts of Speech, Pronouns, Adverbs, Articles, Comparatives)
4. **Phrasal Verbs & Idioms** (Meaning and Usage)
5. **Telephonic Conversation Skills** (Filling Blanks, Appropriate Responses)
6. **Dictionary & Pronunciation Skills** (Word Order, Vowel Sounds)

---

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**

### **1. Reading Comprehension**
- **Key Skills Tested:**
  - Understanding the **main idea** and **supporting details** of a passage.
  - Inferring **implicit meanings** (e.g., "concrete and artificial jungles" = cities).
  - Identifying **tone and purpose** (e.g., appreciating nature for a balanced life).
  - **Vocabulary in context** (e.g., "strife," "unfold," "behold").

- **Passage Used:**
  - A **descriptive passage** on the **beauty of nature**, its **therapeutic effects**, and the **disconnect in modern life**.
  - Key themes:
    - Nature as a **source of joy and tranquility**.
    - **Urbanization vs. natural living** (cities as "artificial jungles").
    - **Historical reverence for nature** (Aryans, Wordsworth).
    - **Modern indifference** due to stress.

- **Question Types:**
  - **Direct questions** (e.g., "What inspired Wordsworth?" → Daffodils).
  - **Inference-based** (e.g., "What leads to a balanced life?" → Enjoying nature).
  - **Vocabulary replacement** (e.g., opposite of "unfold" → "conceal").
  - **Fill-in-the-blanks** (e.g., "Their life is so full of care that _____" → "they have no time to stand and stare").

---

### **2. Vocabulary & Word Usage**
#### **A. Synonyms & Antonyms**
- **Antonym of "unfold"** → **Conceal** (Q3).
- **Synonym of "angry disagreements"** → **Strife** (Q8).

#### **B. Word Sounds (Phonetics)**
- **Words with the sound "/k/"** → **Character, Cataclysm** (but not "Cipher," which starts with "/s/").
- **Words with the "aa" sound** → **Hard** (not "hoard" or "board," which have "/ɔːr/" and "/ɔː/").
- **Words without the "sh" sound** → **Measure** (others: precious, moustache).
- **Vowel sounds in English** → **20** (not just 5 letters; includes diphthongs).

#### **C. Word Collocations (Common Phrases)**
| **Word**   | **Collocation**       | **Example Sentence**                          |
|------------|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Deeply     | Rooted                | "The tradition is deeply rooted in culture." |
| False      | Accusations           | "He made false accusations."                  |
| Hefty      | Price                 | "The hefty price shocked buyers."             |
| Media      | Attention             | "The event gained media attention."           |
| Blowing    | Wind                  | "The blowing wind was strong."               |

---

### **3. Grammar & Syntax**
#### **A. Parts of Speech**
- **"Idea" in "They laughed at my idea"** → **Abstract Noun** (Q15).
- **"Ripe" in "ripe tomatoes"** → **Adjective** (Q20).
- **"Immediately" in "She immediately came"** → **Adverb** (Q22).

#### **B. Pronouns**
- **"Did she see ___?"** → **"Us"** (object pronoun) (Q16).

#### **C. Adverbs vs. Adjectives**
- **"Aparna dances ___"** → **"Beautifully"** (adverb, not "beautiful") (Q17).

#### **D. Comparatives & Superlatives**
- **"Vimal is ___ in his family"** → **"The tallest"** (superlative) (Q21).

#### **E. Articles**
- **"What is ___ time by your watch?"** → **"The"** (specific reference) (Q25).

#### **F. Prepositions & Phrasal Verbs**
- **"Ran out of petrol"** (not "ran out on") (Q23).
- **"Get back to you"** (revert in a call) (Q40).

---

### **4. Idioms & Phrases**
| **Idiom**                     | **Meaning**                          | **Example Usage**                          |
|-------------------------------|--------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------|
| **Cost an arm and a leg**     | Very expensive                       | "The iPhone costs an arm and a leg."      |
| **All Greek to me**           | Incomprehensible                     | "His explanation was all Greek to me."    |
| **Hit on (an idea)**          | Suddenly think of                    | "She hit on a brilliant solution."         |
| **Might (modal verb)**        | Possibility                           | "She might be in her office."              |
| **Must (obligation)**         | Necessity                            | "Students must be 17 to join."             |

---

### **5. Telephonic Conversation Skills**
- **Filling blanks in a call:**
  - **(i) "How may I help you?"** (Polite opening) (Q37).
  - **(ii) "Could I leave him a message?"** (Requesting to convey) (Q38).
  - **(iii) "Your voice is breaking."** (Technical issue) (Q39).
  - **(iv) "Get back to you"** (Promise to revert) (Q40).

---

### **6. Dictionary & Pronunciation Skills**
- **Alphabetical order in dictionaries:**
  - **Correct sequence:** *senile, settee, settle, settlement* (Q18).
- **Pronunciation of "blast":**
  - **Long vowel sound** (like "ah") (Q31).

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**

### **1. Reading Comprehension Topics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Reading Comprehension] --> B[Main Idea]
    A --> C[Supporting Details]
    A --> D[Inference]
    A --> E[Vocabulary in Context]
    B --> F["Nature as a source of joy"]
    C --> G["Stress of modern life"]
    D --> H["Concrete jungles = cities"]
    E --> I["Unfold vs. Conceal"]
```

### **2. Grammar & Vocabulary Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Parts of Speech]
    A --> C[Pronouns]
    A --> D[Adverbs vs Adjectives]
    A --> E[Comparatives]
    B --> F[Nouns: Abstract vs Concrete]
    C --> G[Object Pronouns: Us]
    D --> H["Dances beautifully"]
    E --> I["Tallest in family"]
    A --> J[Articles: The]
```

### **3. Idioms & Phrasal Verbs**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Idioms] --> B["Cost an arm and a leg"]
    A --> C["All Greek to me"]
    A --> D["Hit on an idea"]
    B --> E[Very expensive]
    C --> F[Incomprehensible]
    D --> G[Suddenly think of]
    A --> H[Modal Verbs]
    H --> I[Must: Obligation]
    H --> J[Might: Possibility]
```

### **4. Telephonic Conversation Flow**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Greeting] --> B["How may I help you?"]
    B --> C["May I speak with X?"]
    C --> D["X is not around"]
    D --> E["Could I leave a message?"]
    E --> F["Your voice is breaking"]
    F --> G["I'll get back to you"]
```

### **5. Word Collocations**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Deeply] --> B[Rooted]
    C[False] --> D[Accusations]
    E[Hefty] --> F[Price]
    G[Media] --> H[Attention]
    I[Blowing] --> J[Wind]
```

---
## **Key Equations/Rules (For Grammar & Phonetics)**
Since this is an **English exam**, there are no mathematical equations. However, here are **key rules** to remember:

### **1. Grammar Rules**
1. **Adverbs modify verbs** (e.g., "dances **beautifully**").
2. **Object pronouns** (me, us, him) follow verbs/prepositions (e.g., "see **us**").
3. **Superlatives** use "the + -est" (e.g., "the tallest").
4. **Articles:**
   - "The" for **specific** nouns (e.g., "the time by your watch").
   - "A/An" for **general** nouns (e.g., "a price").

### **2. Phonetics Rules**
1. **Short vs. Long Vowels:**
   - "Blast" has a **long "a"** (like "ah").
   - "Hard" has the **"aa" sound** (like "ah").
2. **Silent Letters:**
   - "C" in "cipher" sounds like "/s/."
   - "Ch" in "character" sounds like "/k/."

### **3. Collocation Rules**
- Some words **commonly pair** with others (e.g., "hefty price," "media attention").

---
## **Final Tips for the Exam**
1. **For Reading Comprehension:**
   - Read the **passage carefully** before answering.
   - Look for **context clues** for vocabulary questions.
   - **Eliminate wrong options** first (e.g., if a word doesn’t fit the tone).

2. **For Grammar:**
   - **Identify the part of speech** being tested (noun, verb, adjective, etc.).
   - **Check subject-verb agreement** and **tense consistency**.

3. **For Vocabulary:**
   - **Memorize common collocations** (e.g., "false accusations").
   - **Practice phonetic sounds** (e.g., "/k/" in "character").

4. **For Telephonic Conversations:**
   - **Use polite and formal language** (e.g., "How may I help you?").
   - **Understand phrasal verbs** like "get back" (revert).

5. **For Idioms:**
   - **Don’t take them literally** (e.g., "cost an arm and a leg" ≠ actual body parts).
   - **Relate to common usage** (e.g., "all Greek to me" = confusing).

---
**Good luck!** Master these topics, and you’ll ace the exam. 🚀
